dataset.title: Macrobenthos Sampling data for the North Inlet Estuary, Georgetown,South Carolina, from 1981 to 1992 North Inlet LTER

abstract.para: This data package consists of Macrobenthos Sampling Data for North Inlet Stations Bread and Butter Creek from 1981 to 1992, and Debidue Creek from 1981 to 1984, North Inlet LTER. The purpose of this study was to document the composition and abundance of macrobenthic subtidal populations over time at one mud and one sand site. Macrobenthos was defined here as those animals retained on a 0.5 mm mesh screen.

section.title: LTER Network Data Access Requirements
section.para:
The access to all LTER data is subject to requirements set forth by this policy document to enable data providers to track usage, evaluate its impact in the community, and confirm users' acceptance of the terms of acceptable use. These requirements are standardized across the LTER Network to provide contractual exchange of data between Site Data Providers, Network Data Providers, and Data Users that can be encoded into electronic form and exchanged between computers. This will allow direct access to data via a common portal once these requirements have been fulfilled. The following information may be required directly or by proxy prior to the transference of any data object:
Registration
Name
Affiliation
Email address
Full Contact Info
Acceptance of the General Public Use Agreement or Restricted Data Use Agreement, as applicable
A Statement of Intended Use that is compliant with the above agreements. Such statements may be made submitted explicitly or made implicitly via the data access portal interface.

section.title: Conditions of Data Use
section.para:
The re-use of scientific data has the potential to greatly increase communication, collaboration and synthesis within and among disciplines, and thus is fostered, supported and encouraged. Permission to use this dataset is granted to the Data User free of charge subject to the following terms:
Acceptable Use. Use of the dataset will be restricted to academic, research, educational, government, recreational, or other not-for-profit professional purposes. The Data User is permitted to produce and distribute derived works from this dataset provided that they are released under the same license terms as those accompanying this Data Set. Any other uses for the Data Set or its derived products will require explicit permission from the dataset owner.
Redistribution. The data are provided for use by the Data User. The metadata and this license must accompany all copies made and be available to all users of this Data Set. The Data User will not redistribute the original Data Set beyond this collaboration sphere.
Citation. It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set. Citation should take the following general form: Creator, Year of Data Publication, Title of Dataset, Publisher, Dataset identifier.
Acknowledgement. The Data User should acknowledge any institutional support or specific funding awards referenced in the metadata accompanying this dataset in any publications where the Data Set contributed significantly to its content. Acknowledgements should identify the supporting party, the party that received the support, and any identifying information such as grant numbers.
Notification. The Data User will notify the Data Set Contact when any derivative work or publication based on or derived from the Data Set is distributed. The Data User will provide the data contact with two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the Data Set and will provide copies, or on-line access to, any derived digital products. Notification will include an explanation of how the Data Set was used to produce the derived work.
Collaboration. The Data Set has been released in the spirit of open scientific collaboration. Data Users are thus strongly encouraged to consider consultation, collaboration and/or co-authorship with the Data Set Creator.
By accepting this Data Set, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. The Data Owner shall have the right to terminate this agreement immediately by written notice upon the Data User's breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. The Data User may be held responsible for any misuse that is caused or encouraged by the Data User's failure to abide by the terms of this agreement.

section.title: Disclaimer
section.para: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation contained in this Data Set, complete accuracy of data and metadata cannot be guaranteed. All data and metadata are made available "as is". The Data User holds all parties involved in the production or distribution of the Data Set harmless for damages resulting from its use or interpretation.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The North Inlet Estuary is located on the southeastern coast of the United States, approximately 10 kilometers east of Georgetown, South Carolina. The North Inlet Estuary is a bar-built Class C type estuary (Pritchard, 1955). It is composed of numerous winding tidal creeks dominated by Spartina alterniflora and is considered a pristine tidal estuary due to minimal anthropogenic impacts. The watershed drains a 24.8 square kilometer area of mostly pine forest and a moderately developed residential watershed to the north. Sample sites were chosen due to their proximity to an existing long-term meiofauna sampling site. Debidue Site (DD): The Debidue Site is located about 500 meters inside the mouth of the inlet, adjacent to the confluence of Debidue and Town Creeks (two major marsh creeks). This site has a sandy bottom and is at the south end of an extensive sand bar. It is subject to strong current and wave action. Debordieu Colony, a large development partially built on man-made canals, drains into the northern portion of Debidue Creek. Bread and Butter Site (BB): This site is located on Bread and Butter Creek, about 600 meters upstream from its juncture with Town Creek, on a muddy subtidal bank. Bread and Butter Creek is a medium sized creek lined with mud banks and oyster bars. The sediment at the sampling site is fine, silty mud and the site is sheltered from strong current and wave action. At low tide the creek is approximately 10 meters wide at the sampling location. The creek is located about 1.5 kilometers southwest of the Debidue site.

section.title: Entry verification
section.para: Multiple levels of entry verification were performed. Data from cruises 1-111 were initially checked for entry errors by Beth Thomas (the data management assistant) who originally entered the data on the full-screen management entry programs. From cruise 112 on, data were entered and checked by Susan Service (Research Specialist). Once all data entry errors are corrected, hard copies of the data (cruises 1-111) on the system were sent to Roberta McCutchen (the Research Specialist who counted the samples) to proof against the original raw data sheets. From cruise 112 on, hard copies were checked by Susan Service. All data on the system from samples 1-111 have been certified error-free by Roberta McCutchen (date 1-21-86). Samples 112-189 have been certified error-free by Susan Service (date 06-14-89). Samples 190-274 were counted and identified by Roberta Woods. The data was entered by Jan Blakely and certified error free by Ginger Ogburn-Matthews.

section.title: Date of last update while at North Inlet LTER
section.para: February 27, 1990

section.title: Last modification at LTER Network Office
section.para: Individual data files (LTER.NIN.MACRO.1981.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1982.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1983.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1984.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1985.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1986.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1987.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1988.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1989.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1990.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1991.txt, LTER.NIN.MACRO.1992.txt) were concatenated into a single file spanning the dates from 1981 to 1992. Original fixed column format was changed to comma separated value format. These changes occured in March 2012

dataset.pubPlace: Long Term Ecological Research Network Office

dataTable.entityDescription: Macrobenthos sampling Data for North Inlet Estuary, South Carolina, from 1981 to 1992, North Inlet LTER

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The North Inlet Estuary is located on the southeastern coast of the United States, approximately 10 kilometers east of Georgetown, South Carolina. The North Inlet Estuary is a bar-built Class C type estuary (Pritchard, 1955). It is composed of numerous winding tidal creeks dominated by Spartina alterniflora and is considered a pristine tidal estuary due to minimal anthropogenic impacts. The watershed drains a 24.8 square kilometer area of mostly pine forest and a moderately developed residential watershed to the north. Sample sites were chosen due to their proximity to an existing long-term meiofauna sampling site. Debidue Site (DD): The Debidue Site is located about 500 meters inside the mouth of the inlet, adjacent to the confluence of Debidue and Town Creeks (two major marsh creeks). This site has a sandy bottom and is at the south end of an extensive sand bar. It is subject to strong current and wave action. Debordieu Colony, a large development partially built on man-made canals, drains into the northern portion of Debidue Creek. Bread and Butter Site (BB): This site is located on Bread and Butter Creek, about 600 meters upstream from its juncture with Town Creek, on a muddy subtidal bank. Bread and Butter Creek is a medium sized creek lined with mud banks and oyster bars. The sediment at the sampling site is fine, silty mud and the site is sheltered from strong current and wave action. At low tide the creek is approximately 10 meters wide at the sampling location. The creek is located about 1.5 kilometers southwest of the Debidue site.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: Two cores were taken fortnightly during the midday low tide at each site. Sampling was done on the same day as all other LTER fauna sampling except when weather conditions, generally east winds that produced higher than usual tides, caused delays. In those cases cores were obtained on the next suitable low tide. The core size and the depth of the core changed over the study period. All changes are given under Section #36, Research Methods. During most of the first four years of the study, a 20 cm long PVC pipe (10.3 cm inside diameter), served as the coring device. Cores were taken to a depth of 15 cm of sediment in 20 cm of water (except when noted under #36 Research Methods).

To determine the depth at which animals occurred in the substrate, cores were split into 5 cm depth increments during the period January 20, 1981 - January 3, 1984 (Cruises 1-74). On occasion the substrate was too watery to section successfully. These instances were also noted in Section #36. From January 16, 1984 - January 8, 1985 (Cruises 75-99), cores continued to be taken to a depth of 15 cm of sediment but were not split.

To compare data from all years when different volumes of sediment were collected and cores were not vertically sectioned into 5 cm increments, data were first changed to numbers per m2. This number was then multiplied by the following factors to equalize data to a number per 5 cm depth:

GROUP SITE BB DD Total Organisms #/0-10 cm 91 86 #/0-15 cm 85 77 Total Polychaetes #/0-10 cm 78 67 #/0-15 cm 66 56 Other Macrofauna #/0-10 cm 77 75 #/0-15 cm 65 62 Starting on January 18, 1985 (Cruise 100), sampling at the Debidue site (DD) was suspended. At the Bread and Butter site (BB) the core size was changed to an 18.1 cm2 area and cores were taken only of the top 5 cm of sediment.

Eight cores were taken in an effort to increase sampling accuracy by decreasing variability between cores. The total area of sediment sampled was similar to that sampled during the previous years. The coring device was a 30 cm length of 48 mm inside diameter Plexiglass pipe. A rubber stopper was used to close the upper end of the pipe to facilitate core removal. Cores were placed directly into Nalgene jars and preserved with a 10 percent buffered formalin-seawater mixture stained with Rose Bengal.

Samples were allowed to rest for at least 48 hours in the preservative before being sieved through a 0.5 mm mesh screen. All material retained on the screen was washed into small counting dishes and the contents sorted with the aid of a dissecting microscope. All animals were identified to the lowest possible category and counted. Animals separated by taxa were placed in storage jars containing a 70 percent Ethanol solution (stock = 95 percent ETOH + tap water + glycerin, 15:5:1 by volume).

All storage jars were labeled by sample with sample date, station (DD or BB), and jar number. Each jar contained a label inside with the above information and the identity of the animals contained. The jar numbers corresponded to those listed on the original count sheets. Example: A jar labelled 04/18/81 D1 Top #4 Spiophanes bombyx contained all Spiophanes bombyx found at Debidue station, Replicate 1, in the top 5 cm of sediment and was the fourth jar in that replicate.

This system allowed ready access to any specimen collected. Samples for years 1981 through 1984 have been archived and stored in sealed quart jars and collected in boxes in the preserved samples shed at the field lab. Samples were indexed by cruise and box. Index sheets were stored 1) with the boxes and 2) in the Research Specialist's office at the field lab. Original count sheets listed the identities and numbers of all animals collected, comments and physical measurements at each site. These sheets were stored in fire-proof cabinets. A second set of data sheets used for computer entry were stored separately. Numbers for each cruise were entered shortly after processing on the Full Screen Manager. Beginning in May 1986, biomass was determined for selected samples.

Three additional cores were collected at the Bread and Butter subtidal site. These cores were processed in the same manner as described above, however the preserved animals picked out of the samples were first rinsed thoroughly in fresh water and then placed in preweighed aluminum pans. These pans were oven-dried at 60 degrees C for 24 hours, or until a constant weight had been attained. These data tracked monthly changes in the total biomass of an 18.1 cm square area. Biomass data on a species level was obtained in another manner.

Qualitative samples were collected periodically and preserved animals were identified and placed into species-specific size classes. Width of the first setigerous segment of polychaetes, in micrometer units at 12X, was used to place polychaetes into size classes (Some of the larger polychaetes were measured at lower powers). The width of the first setigerous segment of Oligochaetes was measured at 12X. The carapace length of amphipods and cumaceans was measured at 25X and 12X, respectively. Isopods and shrimp were measured at 12X while bivalves were measured at the longest anterior-posterior dimension at 12X. Several specimens of each size class of each species were placed in preweighed aluminum pans. Each size class/species pan was replicated at least 3 times. All pans were oven-dried at 60 degree C for 24 hours or until a constant weight was attained. An average weight was calculated for each size class and pan and for each species a width (or length)/weight regression was calculated. With these regressions, average biomass on a species level could be quantitatively determined from the biweekly samples by simply measuring the appropriate dimension under the microscope and using the regression equation.
The following regression equations were obtained for various macrobenthic taxa.
All regressions used natural log(ln)-transformed data and weights were dried weights in mg. Size was in ocular micrometer units from the ocular micrometer in the macrobenthic dissecting scope.
TAXON REGRESSION EQUATION R**2
Streblospio benedicti ln(weight)=3.485[ln(size)]-8.07 0.968
Mediomastus ambiseta ln(weight)=2.766[ln(size)]-6.35 0.957
Cirratulidae ln(weight)=1.96[ln(size)]-5.736 0.852 Oligochaetes
ln(weight)=2.08[ln(size)]-6.255 0.953 Juvenile Bivalves

section.title: Research Methods
section.para: The number of cores taken at the Debidue site (DD) and the Bread and Butter site (BB) remained at two from January 20, 1981 (Cruise 1) through January 8, 1985 (Cruise 99). Starting on January 18, 1985 the Debidue site was dropped and eight smaller cores were taken at the Bread and Butter site.

section.title: Lab: biomass conversions
section.para: The following biomass conversions were obtained seasonally for abundant taxa and over the entire year for less abundant taxa. Each number was the average weight of an individual of a given taxa, expressed in micrograms fresh (non-preserved) organic carbon. Biomass values obtained for preserved specimens were converted to non-preserved values following the procedures of Frithsen et al (Frithsen, JB, DT Rudnick, PH Doering. 1986. The determination of fresh organic weight from formaldehyde preserved macrofaunal samples. Hydrobiologia 133:203-208) TAXA MAY AUG NOV FEB MAY Mediomastus ambiseta 30.83 20.56 13.88 30.83 24.67 Streblospio benedicti 24.81 10.98 10.52 58.64 22.55 Cirratulidae 19.97 14.59 60.66 20.73 29.94 Oligochaetes 10.75 9.98 9.98 21.50 6.91 Bivalves not shelled 14.10 21.42 17.84 41.19 14.10 Syllidae 9.83 Orbinidae 18.43 Eteone heteropoda 66.03 Lumbrineridae 147.42 Nereidae 99.82 Glyceridae and Goniadidae 253.38 Prionospio cirrifera 36.09 Armandia maculata 146.04 Beginning with cruise 112 (07-15-85), only dominant polychaetes were identified to species. The Full Screen Manager format was reduced from 11 to 3 screens by this procedure and data were entered on the field lab's Digital system. The same 3 screen system was in use on the IBM PC, beginning with cruise 169. Data were uploaded to the mainframe system after being certified error-free. For comparison with data entered beginning with cruise 112 (07-15-85) any families (and their associated species) identified on old data sheets that were not identified on the new format were lumped under the "unidentified Polychaete" category. Other species of polychaetes in the families Cirratulidae, Glyceridae, Goniadidae, Lumbrineridae, Nereidae, Orbinidae, Spionidae, Magelonidae, Phyllodocidae, Syllidae and Capitellidae that were identified under the old format were lumped into the "unidentified" category of their respective family for analysis. In the new format, the category "shrimp" included the following from the old format: Alpheus normanni, Calianassa sp., Ogyrides limicola, Palaemonetes sp., P. pugio, P. vulgaris and Penaeid shrimps. Osyurostylis smithi on the old data sheets were included in the category "cumaceans". Categories "amphipod" and "isopod" remained the same in both data formats. Any other crustaceans identified in the old format were included in the new category "unidentified Crustaceans"
